text:
Our speaker today
is Gordon Moore who is Chairman of
the Board of Intel Corporation, a major
supplier of microprocessors

and other useful things. And he's going to talk today
about VLSI industry trends,

technological and economic. Gordon. OK, well, thank you. I'll hide over here
behind the lectern

to get out from the
way of my own slides. This year, the integrated
circuit is 30 years old.

It's old enough that
I read in the paper last week that TI is
getting their patent issued

in Japan finally. [LAUGHTER] And I am repeatedly amazed at
what we can design and build.

I've been involved
in this industry since the beginning of
the integrated circuit,

in fact before that. But not long ago, I would
have had a difficult time

accepting the fact
that we could either design a million transistor
circuit covering a chip maybe

a 1/2 a square inch, or that
if we were able to design it, that we'd be able to make it.

Now we not only expect to
be able to make such things, but we expect to be
able to make them

so they work the first time. We've really come a tremendous
way in this 30 years.

And I think it's fair, and
perhaps appropriate, to ask,

is the technology getting
anywhere near saturation? That is, are we going to be able
to continue the progress we've

made in designing and making
the integrated circuits as the technology
becomes fully developed?

And we could ask, where is
the technology likely to go-- technically or
geographically, I suppose--

and even what drives it. So today, what
I'm going to do is stand back and take the 20-
or 30-year view of what's

been going on in the
industry, and try to make some broad
extrapolations,

and hopefully draw some
conclusions about what

is happening, what has
happened, and therefore maybe we can figure out what might
happen in the future.

First, I think it's useful
to sit back and say, what's made this technology
so powerful already?

Clearly, it has had a
very important impact and has been able to evolve
rapidly for 30 years or more.

And I think the reason
this has happened is we've been exploiting a
violation of Murphy's law.

By making things
smaller, everything gets better simultaneously. Essentially, you don't
trade anything off.

The things get
faster, the electrons don't have so far to move. Clearly, we can cut
the power consumption.

The systems made
become more reliable because we can go to higher
levels of integration on a given silicon chip.

And we've been able to keep the
reliability per silicon chip at least constant irrespective
of what we stick on the chip.

But most important,
as we've progressed along higher levels
of integration,

we've been able to
make things cheaper. The cost of doing things
electronically in the 30 years

since the invention of
the integrated circuit has dropped a millionfold
in many cases.

The easiest place to see that
is you can buy a megabit DRAM today for less
than Fairchild sold

its first individual silicon
transistors for 35 years ago.

I remember those
first transistors. We sold them for $150 apiece. Now a megabit DRAM that
not only includes well

over a million transistors,
but all the circuit design and interconnections that
go along with itself,

are far less than the same thing
as the individual transistor.

I've often used an
analogy about this. What would have
happened if the auto industry had advanced that
rapidly during these last 30

years? And you come to the conclusion
a million mile an hour,

1/2 a million miles
to the gallon of gas. It would be cheaper to
throw away your Rolls Royce

and buy a new one than to park
it downtown for the evening. But of course, you wouldn't
have to throw it away.

Its reliability would
be such you would you could pass it on
for several generations. Well, I thought this
was pretty good,

though one time somebody in
the audience pointed out to me it'd only be 2 inches
long and a 1/2 inch high. It wouldn't be much good
for my morning commute.

But I think as you look
at an industry that's

decreased the cost of its
product a millionfold, what

one characteristic does
that industry have to have? It has to sell a heck
of a lot more of them

at the end of that time than
it did in the beginning.

We clearly have to sell a
lot more than a million times as many transistors today as
we did 30 years ago to make up

for this. So I think that's the slide
I'd like to start with. And a lot of respect--

it's going to be the
most important slide I have concerning
what's been required

to make this industry go. And that is my curve
of market elasticity.

And I'm going to generally be
looking at the same time scale

as we go through the various
slides about the last 20 years, which coincidentally
matches Intel's history.

We were formed in '68. But if you look at this
estimate of the total number

of transistors
produced in the world, you see that it is on
a curve that goes up

a factor of 10 about
every three years for the average slope in there.

A factor of 10
every three years. If it doubled every year,
it would be a factor of 8

in three years. So the amount of
transistors the industry builds more than
doubles every year.

Although the nature
of a series that does that, it means
that during this year, we will build more
electronic function than

existed in the
world on January 1. It's a phenomenally
elastic market,

more elastic than any other
one I've ever been able to see. Now, I got a little
chicken on the slope

up here in the upper end. Because frankly, it
gets increasingly hard to identify
applications that

use 10 to the 15th
transistors per year. That's a million transistors
for every man, woman, and child

in the developed world.  It is really a phenomenal
amount of electronics.

And I think you people
have probably all used your million transistors
and then some this year.

But you have to look
forward to the two million next year, four or five million
the year after, and so forth.

And you have to bring all your
friends from the liberal arts division along with you if we're
going to keep on this curve.

I used to have a difficult time
generating points for this. I had to go down through
all the products made,

estimate how many transistors
they had, and add them up. And it probably could get
precise within a factor of 2.

In recent years,
all I have to do is count the number of DRAM
bits and multiply that by 2, and I'm well within
a factor of 2.

It turns out it's gotten
easier rather than more difficult as time has gone on.

Well, let's look at
a few other trends. One that we alluded
to earlier is the fact

that we continually make
smaller and smaller structures. This has been on a quite
good exponential curve

with a slope of about a
factor of 2 every six years. And I could actually extrapolate
that back another decade,

and it would still
be on the same slope. Every six years, we can cut our
minimum dimensions in halves.

And it has continued without
any real sign of saturation. Now, saturation
has been predicted

in this curve about every
two years for the last decade or more.

We didn't think
we'd get anywhere near a micron optically. But in fact, we not
only got to a micron,

we now expect to use optical
lithography techniques to at least to a 1/2
a micron, and probably

to 3/10 of a micron, and clearly
well beyond my retirement.

It is amazing how this
limit has continued to recede as we've pushed
further and further to make

the smaller structures. We've decreased structures
a hundredfold in dimensions

without yet approaching any
kind of a fundamental limit. There's some indication
that maybe around 1/10th

of a micron for
minimum structures, we'll start to see some
effects that will make life

more difficult. But for
the time being at least, we think we're on this
track of continuing

to make things smaller
without any real problems. In the other direction,
we've had a similar trend

toward making
structures thinner. In a lot of respects, this one
surprises me significantly more

than the narrower lines. I expected we'd be getting
insignificant problems when

we got the film thicknesses of
the order of 1,000 angstroms. I felt that 20
years ago at least.

Because on the back
of an envelope, you can convince yourself
that if these films come down

as statistical piles
of atoms, that you start to see huge
variations in the thickness

when you got down to
that kind of a range. So the electrical properties
wouldn't behave well.

But this clearly
hasn't happened. Working on down to films below
100 angstroms in thickness--

I got a little aggressive on the
curve out here at the tail end, we don't work much below
100 angstroms these days--

where you only have the
order of 10 atomic layers, these things still
behave beautifully.

No signs of the kind
of statistical holes that I thought we
were going to get.

Clearly, it's not a
random phenomenon. The forces on our side, chemical
forces in this instance,

and these things actually
tend to work in our favor rather than against us.

Again, we're
trifling with Murphy, I think, in the way this goes. Here though, we actually
are approaching a limit.

And on these thin
films, we're down at the point where
we can actually see quantum mechanical
tunneling through them.

Instead of that being
a problem so far, we've exploited it in some
of the electrically erasable

memories. But we can't expect to
go an awful lot further on that particular limit
because we're actually

starting to reach a
fundamental limitation. Taking another cut
at it, we can look

at the charge necessary
to separate a 1 or a 0 in several generations
of EPROMs in this case.

It's unusual. I count transistors by
saying 10 to the 15th. I count charge by saying
100,000 electrons.

This is the opposite way we
would have talked about things 20 or 30 years ago where
charges that we dealt

with were 10 to the 15th
electrons and the number

of transistors were down
in reasonable numbers. But here again, we
have a trend that

has remained quite constant. We cut the charge about a
factor of 2 every generation

of memory products and show
little sign of it rounding off. Now, we're up to the
4-megabit EPROMs these days.

And I'll admit I
didn't update my curve to see if we're still on this. But I'm sure we're
well under 100,000

electrons on the stored charge. And in spite of
that, we still expect to get 100-year retention
of this kind of a memory,

longer than we ever would have
committed a decade or more ago.

Let's take another one of these. Let's take DRAMs. And here the world hasn't
been quite so uniform.

We were coming down the
same kind of a curve until the 64K DRAM when all of
a sudden we ran into a problem.

The memories were forgetting
a bit now and then. Big systems built out of
the initial 64K 4k DRAMs

tend to make soft errors,
non-repeatable loss of data in the memory.

And this was tracked down, after
rather extensive investigations,

to being the result of residual
alpha particles coming out of the packaging material. One alpha particle made
enough whole electron pairs

that could actually erase
the data in a DRAM bit. Of course, there are a
lot of solutions to that.

One is to clean up your
packaging materials to cut the incidence
of alpha particles. The other is to try to put
some kind of a layer on there

that absorbs them. Those things were done. But in addition, we had to
jack the number of electrons

back up so they were not
sensitive to a single alpha particle error. And now, it's flattened out
at around a million electrons

necessary to be sure
you're not going to get a problem from a
single alpha particle.

This is the one place I can
identify where we've actually run across some kind of a
relatively fundamental that

a limit that we
had to live with. It's also the reason that
the DRAM technologies

have gotten so darn complex. You can't continue to scale
capacitors as time goes on.

You have to go in
there and figure out how to get enough capacitance
in the small area. So people are going to
three-dimensional structures

with deep trenches into the
silicon and things like that in order to get a capacitor
of sufficient area to get your million
electrons on there so we have

alpha particle insensitivity. I think had it been any product
except DRAMs, which is the macho

product for the
semiconductor industry, we would have
relaxed and enjoyed the technology we had
available and stopped

at a much lower density
than we're still fighting to achieve on
the new products today.

Well, let's turn in a
slightly different direction and look at another
technological trend,

and this is what's
happened to our defects during this time period. This is a very important
change in that we've finally

worked ourselves out of a rut. We used to develop a technology,
stick it into manufacturing

at relatively low yield or
relatively high defect density, massage the process
and the product

until we got higher yields. Just about the time we were
doing pretty well, 20%,

30% yield, we'd find we
got an economic advantage by scaling the geometry,
which redefines the defect--

smaller ones now affect
you-- going back in again at high-defect
densities and low yields and working ourselves
around that loop.

Made a lot of progress
that way, but we were changing
generations of technology as fast as we were
decreasing defects.

So we didn't make any
real progress for a while. The last couple of generations,
we've broken out of that.

We're starting at
lower defect densities and taking them down to
much lower defect densities.

And this, of course, has
significant implications on what the designer can
consider in terms of chip size

and so forth. We can make very much larger
devices today than we used to. In fact, today, it is an
occasional event at least

to see a perfect wafer, that is,
one where every circuit on it is good.

I have Intel's first 100%-yield
wafer hanging on my office wall. I've heard rumors of competitors
having 100%-yield runs where

every wafer in the
run was 100% yield. I'll have to admit I've
yet to see one of those.

But 100%-yield wafers are
something that would be hard to conceive of looking
back in, say, the mid '70s.

So a tremendous amount of
progress has been made there. And I think it really means we
can seriously consider things

like wafer scale integration
where the whole wafer is built into a system should there be
another good reason for doing

that. As a result, our chip
sizes can get bigger.

And they've grown about
an order of magnitude in area over Intel's history,
as well as increasing

1,000 times or
more in complexity during this time period. So we now have an allowed
range of product complexity.

And here I'm really on memory
thinking logic circuits, for example, where you
can make anything you want

that falls in that red area. So million-transistor
logic circuits

now are straightforward to do. In fact, we've introduced
a few of them this year. The next generation,
staying on this curve,

we'll look at four or
five million transistors in the next generation
of microprocessors.

And I don't see why we ought
to be falling off this curve. And if you extrapolate
this to the year 2000,

you conclude that
we can be looking at a logic circuit
with something in the 50 to 100 million
transistors on it.

It actually extrapolates closer
to 100 than it does to 50. I don't quite know what to do
with 100 million transistors

worth of logic on a chip yet. I think every logic
function we've ever built could be put on one chip with
this level of complexity.

And I think it really is
a challenge to figure out what to do with it.

But this challenge is not new. I picked a slide here,
which I have on its side,

but you can rotate
that 90 degrees. This shows the design
effort versus time to make

the state-of-the-art logic
chips over a period of time. And I actually used this slide
in a solid-state circuits

conference keynote
address, I think in 1979, showing that we were
having the problem where

the cost of designing
these things was absolutely skyrocketing
on us and something that we weren't going
to be able to continue

to live with because the
investment was going up so dramatically.

In fact, at that time, and
actually for somewhat longer than this slide shows-- this
curve should have come out here

a ways before it fell down-- it was taking about a
constant effort per transistor

in the completed
circuit to design it. This is kind of the hardware
equivalent of the productivity

of a programmer being
so many lines of code irrespective of the time. We had the same kind of a
problem in the hardware area.

We'd get about the same
number of transistors designed per day per person
involved in the design.

Now, this was still
pretty darn good. This took a lot of computer
age, and one thing or another, to stay at that
because it would be

easy to imagine the
design effort would go up with some power function with
the number of transistors.

But with CAD and systematic
design technology, we've been able to overcome
this now and get to the point

where, for only a slowly
growing size design team, we can make increasingly
complex integrated circuits.

This really lets us use
this processing technology

that I showed in
the previous slide so we can actually fill that
entire red area on product

complexity.  Well, moving in
another direction--

and this one, of all
the slides I'm showing, doesn't have real data in it.

It's just my guess
of what's happening. That's the growth in the number
of different semiconductor products.

With the ASIC technology that's
gotten pretty widely distributed and a lot of systems designers
making their own circuits now,

we've had an explosion in
the different functions that are out there.

This has a lot of implications
for the manufacturer. It means each one of these can't
be considered a separate product

and put through its own
separate reliability testing, for example, because
there just is not enough

capability to handle that. We have to qualify
generically the process.

Similarly, the designs have
to work the first time. So we have to qualify
the design technology

rather than go through
and exhaustively try to test each of the
products that comes out.

I think it's a real
control problem and one that has significant
impact on the industry, although less impact
directly on the users
than do a variety of others. Moving to another trend--

and I'll get down to the
processing technology. Our processes have continued
to grow in complexity.

When I look at this,
it's hard to realize that the principal initial
argument for MOS over bipolar

was the greater
process simplicity. It only used four masking
steps instead of six.

We've sure succeeded in
changing that over the years. Here I picked some
EPROM processes here

on this particular curve. We're getting to
the point now where new processes are of the
order of 20 masking steps.

The new DRAM processes are in
that level of complexity also. The logic processes with three
layers of interconnections

tend to be in the high teens. We really have succeeded in
making this a lot more complex.

And of course,
masking steps are only a good proxy for the
total process complexity.

Each of these usually requires
a deposition, a masking, an etching, some kind of a
heat treatment, probably a 1/2

a dozen or more major
process steps for each mask. These things have gotten
tremendously complex.

But even during this,
the defect density has dropped dramatically.

What it gets tied to though
is a tremendous increase in the cost of developing
another generation of process.

And this actually
was the Intel data. In '68, we started out.

We developed two major
new processes as well as our initial products and
put them in production for less than $3 million.

Our latest process of
the order of $60 million to develop and get
running in production.

The one difference
here is that I'm now including some of the
engineering necessary to get

to high yields. Looking at that
curve, would anybody want to guess when the Japanese
started to become important

in this business? You're right. It's right there at
the knee of the curve.

It really took off. And it has gotten exceedingly
difficult to get a leadership

position in the industry based
on the processing technology. This is kind of
qualitative data also.

But if you assume that the
industry leaders, the people that generally have the
top products out there,

they say the 1/2 dozen
companies that are more or less parallel in technology
at any time, 1 spend one unit on
getting their position.

If you wanted to try to
get a year ahead of that, we estimate it would
take probably 3

times that expenditure to do,
just to pull everything in that far. There you have to
develop a large portion

of your own equipment. You have a lot of
additional loads that you take on
yourself that don't

exist if you're going along
generally with the leading edge. The net result is nobody has a
year's lead anymore in general

on the technology, maybe on
some particular part of it where they've invented
a new structure, but not in the
mainstream technology.

And if you want to lag
behind a couple of years, you can do it very cheaply. You can pick up what
other people did.

And that's been a
viable strategy for some of the companies in there.

But the point here is
that where a major portion of the industry's
advantage used to be

in sustaining some kind of
a technological advantage in the processing, that has
gotten very, very difficult

to do. And it's hard to see any
sustainable advantage there anymore. So increasingly, we try to be
competitive in the processing

technology and get our
advantage in the product design in order to maintain a
really viable business.

Well, other parts
of the business

have gotten more expensive also. For example, if we
look at the cost of various pieces
of equipment-- these

are several major
pieces of equipment-- you see their costs have grown
roughly on the exponential scale

during this time period also. When Intel started in '68,
a given piece of equipment

cost about $12,000,
and you could buy a lithography machine, or a
bank of furnaces, or a sputter.

It was around
$10,000 or $12,000. In the one-micron generation,
it was closer to $1.2 million.

It had gone up 100-fold in the
cost of a piece of equipment. In the next generation, we're
looking at pieces of equipment

that individually cost two to
$3 million in several cases. Now, the discouraging
part of this

is the throughput of
these pieces of equipment is about the same
in 1968 as in 1988.

They still get their
20 wafers per hour through or whatever
the nominal number is. The only real
difference in the output

is that the wafers are
bigger than they used to be. So the cost of the equipment
is growing dramatically,

so the business has become
a lot more capital-intensive during this time period
than it was two decades ago.

A significant
semiconductor plant now, one to make volume products,
costs about as much

as a significant steel mill.  Our Albuquerque plant, which
is four different processing

modules, by the time it's filled
will cost well over $600 million for the building plus the
equipment it contains.

I say well over because
the last couple of modules aren't yet committed,
and each one

is sequentially costing quite a
bit more than the previous one.

The net result is if you look
at the cost of a facility that

is reasonably well balanced
from a production point of view, this is the cost of capital
to process about 1,000 wafers

a week. A minimum balance facility, that
is, where one piece of equipment

isn't kept waiting
because it has more capacity than the other,
is probably a couple of 1,000 wafer starts a week.

So a reasonably competitive
manufacturing facility has to have about $100 million
worth of equipment in it

at the current generations,
or the 8/10-micron generation that's just moving
on into production,

and would probably have
more than that to get better utilization.

If anything, the 1/2-micron
generation is significantly understated in this curve.

So the first thing
you see, thinking how capital intensive this
was, that this is clearly

not a business for startups. So we look at the new
semiconductor company formations

over this time period, and
we see, well, it may not be a business for startups.

The people that finance
startups didn't realize this during most of this time period.

By the way, this curve has some
other interesting things on it. It shows you the dates of
the changes in the tax law.

This was the introduction
of the 1969 tax law, which is significant
increase in capital gains tax.

There was the '79 tax law change
that decreased the capital gains tax.

And then it came back
again in the '80s. It's probably understated
here at this end because you don't pick up all
of the startups in something

like this. Because some of them are
invisible for a few years before they're picked up. So in spite of this
capital intensity,

we had a huge
increase in the number of semiconductor startups. In fact, we can integrate that.

I'm just out of phase
with the lights, I see. And this is a
pretty good measure of the total number of
semiconductor companies

in the world. Did a little bit more
than integrated that. I added in the
foreign companies.

But in this curve, they
don't make much difference because they're lost in the
noise of all the US companies.

And I accounted for some of the
ones that went out of business or were combined with others. So we have an industry
here that has something

over 200 companies involved in
it, most of them US companies.

And something like that is
clearly a highly fractionated business, you might think.

But if you look
at it another way, you see that, in fact, the
business is done principally

by a relatively few companies. Here I took MOS/LSI instead
of the total semiconductor

industry. They're not very
different in this curve, but you see that
something approaching 70% of the dollars,
2/3 of the business,

is done by the top 10
companies, and 30% of it

is actually done by
about the top three. So you have an
industry here that

has a lot of little companies,
a few medium-sized companies, and a very few very
large companies.

So it looks like
an industry, viewed at this level, that is dominated
by this 10 very big companies.

Well, that's fine, except if
you look one step different

and look at the 10
companies, the thing you see is they're not the same 10.

Now, this is color
coded on this slide. The blue companies are US
based, the red companies

are Japanese based, and
the green company is other.

Of course, the trend you see
here is the graph or the table gets a lot redder as
you go to the right.

And you might think this
is terrible performance

on the part of the US industry. Well, take a particular
example, or let's take

Texas Instruments, for example. They went from 65
million to 238 to 572

to 1,275,000,000 in revenue
during this time period.

Now, this is really a growth
that most companies would

be extremely happy to
have, growing, what's that, 20-fold over the 20 years.

Unprecedented in most
other industries. It was good enough to
go from first place to eighth place in this case.

In these five year periods
with one minor exception, the 10th largest
company is bigger

than the largest one was
five years previously. So it's been a phenomenal
growth industry.

But the real rapid
growers have turned out to be the Japanese companies.

Now, I expect that
this will continue to change because there
are a lot of other people

who are trying to get in to
the 1993 version of that.

We have at least three
major Korean companies that are aggressively pursuing this.

I suspect, in fact, Samsung
will be in the top 10

if not next year, the year
after, certainly by the 1993

update I do with this plot. You've got companies
like Philips and Siemens in Europe who are strongly
dedicated to a major position

in the semiconductor industry. You have new entries coming
in from some of the developing

countries. Taiwan is aggressively
going after this business. So I think we're going to
continue to see a lot of changes

of the players in this top 10. And those of us who
are there don't want to get pushed out very easily.

So this has been a broad overall
view of some of the trends in the semiconductor industry.

We looked at some
that were technical, some that were financial,
and some that are structural.

I think overall,
it's something that really has shown
phenomenal progress over this period of time.

In fact, it's unprecedented
in its rate of change as near as I can see. The millionfold-plus decrease in
the cost combined with the fact

that a technology that didn't
even exist when most of you

were born has
become so important in this 20-year period.

It's really been an
exciting rollercoaster ride, but might take a
look at what it's

going to take to keep
it going like this. And I kind of see three things
here we have to worry about.

One of them I'll call
driving the machine. This business and
its rapid growth

continue to depend on
the market expansion in order to be able to
afford the investment

to keep the technology moving. You really have to look. Have you used your million
transistors yet this year?

This is the question
it comes down to. Where do we find
applications for 10 to the 16th transistors
a year or 10

to the 17th transistors a year? How can we use this much
electronic function?

I think we can wave our hands
and see some things that could produce the kind of
requirements we're after there.

The real-time speech recognition
is one of my favorites so I can talk to my
PC instead of having

to fumble over the keyboard. That can use more bits and
mips than about anything

I can think of. But those are the kinds of
things you have to have. In order to use these huge
numbers of electronic functions,

you have to come up
with an application that you can multiply by
the population of the world,

or by the number of
households in the world, or something like that. It can't be something that
sits one per major university

and have any real
